captions.text:
If there&#39;s one major indictment of our current
era, besides the chocolate syrup they serve

with the brownies at Domino&#39;s Pizza that&#39;s
like dipping them in slightly viscous water,
it&#39;s anti-intellectualism.

It&#39;s been on the rise ever since the word
&#39;scientist&#39; started comfortably fitting after
the word &#39;mad&#39;.

But you know what, you&#39;re not meeting everyone
else halfway, scientists.

When you go around saying &quot;My education is
based on the groundwork of tens of thousands

of years of progress and strict scientific
rigour and that is why I am a better authority

on my sphere of expertise than a suburban
housewife who half-remembers a facebook post

she read once&quot;, well that&#39;s the kind of superior
attitude that makes people stop vaccinating
their kids out of spite.

If you want to start turning things around,
science, I can think of one place to start:

stop ruining everyone&#39;s fun when it comes
to dinosaurs.

I&#39;ve never met a dinosaur that a scientist
hasn&#39;t tried to ruin.

Jurassic Park comes out and everyone&#39;s enjoying
the T-Rex and the velociraptors but then Johnny

Scientist jumps up and goes &quot;Um actually we
did a little bit more science and we&#39;ve learned

that velociraptors were two foot tall and
feathered and could be trained to fetch slippers.

Also the T-rex was more of a scavenger than
a hunter and all the other dinosaurs used

to bully it and knock its schoolbooks out
of its tiny pathetic arms.&quot;

Well, for the record Jurassic World Evolution
is staying consistent with the films with

velociraptors being the prickliest little
madams in the daycare centre.

Which kinda compromises its usefulness as
a learning resource.

And that&#39;s a shame, because the whole &quot;fun
and entertaining to play&quot; thing didn&#39;t work
out either.

But let&#39;s not oversalt the pudding before
the first thrust.

Jurassic World Generic Subtitle is a business
management sim wherein our task is to wave

our corporate botties at the lessons of history
and build a bunch of all new dinosaur parks

for rich white tourists to come and look at
who I guess aren&#39;t satisfied with just taking

a nice holiday on an unspoilt tropical island,
no, they&#39;ve got to see some perversions of

nature as well, so that Mrs. Klebold from
next door doesn&#39;t show them up again with
her pictures from her trip to Eurodisney.

So we&#39;re given an island and we usually kick
off by building a simple enclosure with some

nice, boring, unfussy dinosaurs who don&#39;t
mind posing for selfies, stick a gift shop

opposite so the plebs can buy struthiomimus
T-shirts and wait for enough money to accrue
that you can build something sexier.

And you know what, the park executives in
the films must have spent all their time coked

to the eyebrows because it turns out stopping
dinosaurs from escaping is easy peasy Murdoch
sleazy.

If only Richard Attenborough had known that
you just have to click on each dinosaur and

a bunch of meters will pop up showing exactly
what makes them comfortable with regards to

enclosure size, terrain type, diet, whether
you&#39;re piping in death metal or Barry Manilow,
etc.

You have the omnipotence of a fickle creator
God when it comes to landscaping so all you

have to do is adjust the environment according
to their preferences and they instantly stop

banging their heads on the walls and become
nice as pie.

You don&#39;t even need the electrified barrier
at that point, a white picket fence will keep
&#39;em in.

Having said that, earlier on before I noticed
the stat screen and had one or two incidents

where I didn&#39;t notice a small gap in the fence
because I couldn&#39;t see it through the fucking
trees, I did have a couple of escape incidents.

This was when I discovered there is literally
fuck all you can do about escaped dinosaurs
if you haven&#39;t got a helipad.

Only helicopters can tranquillise the slippery
little fucks so if it&#39;s still early and you

can&#39;t afford one yet then all you can do is
hope to God it just wants to steal the candy
floss and get in a few photobombs.
I had jeeps.

I had jeeps for days, each one equipped with
a dude with a dart rifle, but the only darts

you can fire from jeeps are healing darts
and that&#39;s sending entirely the wrong message

to a ceratosaurus that&#39;s chewing on the bottom
two thirds of a little screaming lawsuit in
waiting.

So if I were you I&#39;d stick to herbivores until
you&#39;ve got a helipad &#39;cos I guess there&#39;s

some real arbitrary dickishness going on at
the dart rifle firer&#39;s union.
Carnivores are just complete pricks.

That&#39;s another thing I had to learn early
on: don&#39;t put carnivores and herbivores in
the same enclosure.
Oh really, Yahtz?
Thanks for the insider tip.

Don&#39;t forget to remind us not to mistake an
orbital sander for a wanking sock.
Alright, it seems obvious now.

I just assumed it&#39;d be fine as long as everyone
was high on comfort and had readily available
food.

But nope, carnivores just have the prick gene
and will murder any herbivore it sees even

if it&#39;s full, content and getting regular
pedicures.

But after you learn these lessons, running
the parks is very straightforward, and here

we get to the central awkward truth of Jurassic
World Ebola Virus: that the interesting part

of Jurassic Park the film was not the part
where everything was going swimmingly.

To spice things up, we&#39;re given tasks by our
three company divisions: the science division

who think we&#39;re running a research facility,
the entertainment division who think we&#39;re

running a theme park, and the security division
who I guess think we&#39;re running a prison for
dinosaur drug dealers or something.

Complete a task for one and you&#39;ll lose points
with the other two, which feels like drawing

things out unnecessarily and doesn&#39;t point
to a terribly healthy work environment, but

it&#39;s particularly odd when they all give you
the same tasks.

Entertainment man says &quot;Hatch a stegosaurus
because people think they&#39;re cool.&quot;

Science lady says &quot;Hatch a stegosaurus because
we need to research how cool they are for

science&quot; and security dude says &quot;Hatch a stegosaurus
because we&#39;re gonna put targets on its back
plates and use it as a firing range.&quot;

Actually I don&#39;t mind the missions because
I like business sims to be goal-oriented and

don&#39;t see much appeal in just sitting on a
perfectly functional park accruing more imaginary

money than I know what to fantasise about
doing with.

But at the same time, I do think Jurassic
World: Electric Boogaloo is a bit thin and
lacking the personal touch.

All the spaces you&#39;re given to develop in
are kinda pokey and the range of buildings

is small and low on options, there is one
and only one kind of restaurant you can stamp

out when your park is scoring low on food
availability, it is simply named &quot;Fast Food&quot;

and I assume it sells everything in featureless
grey packaging like an Australian tobacconist.

You can rename your brontosaurus Sergeant
Bellend and paint him in khaki brown instead

of khaki green, and that&#39;s about it as far
as personalisation goes, but he&#39;ll still have

infinitely more personality than the human
guests.

Human beings just seem to grow on the walkways
like a fungus.

You get money just from Captain Generic&#39;s
Tolerable Fast Food Emporium existing and

not from how many individual guests pass through
it, which I guess is fine, but it does mean

it&#39;s hard to sympathise when the attractions
bust out and start chewing on them.

Even more so when they all gamely come straight
back the moment the threat is gone, already

thinking about what a funny story this will
make when they explain it to child protection
services.

I dunno, I guess I just like to know who a
person is as I&#39;m picking their dentures out
of the T-rex&#39;s litter box.
